original_table_html:
| OBJECTIVE 3-1                  | OBJECTIVE 3-2                          | OBJECTIVE 3-3                          | OBJECTIVE 3-4                  |
|-------------------------------|--------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Marketing environment (p 92)  | Demography (p 96)                    | Natural environment (p 104)          | Political environment (p 108) |
| Microenvironment (p 92)        | Baby boomers (p 97)                  | Environmental sustainability (p 105)| Cultural environment (p 111)  |
| Macroenvironment (p 92)        | Generation X (p 97)                  | Technological environment (p 106)   |                               |
| Marketing intermediaries (p 94)| Millennials (Generation Y) (p 98)   |                                      |                               |
| Public (p 95)                  | Generation Z (p 99)                  |                                      |                               |
|                               | Economic environment (p 103)         |                                      |                               | Go to **mymktlab.com** to complete the problems marked with this icon icon.
summary_markdown: This table outlines four distinct marketing objectives, each focusing on a different facet of the marketing environment. Objective 3-1 examines the broader marketing environment, encompassing its microenvironment and macroenvironment, along with key players like marketing intermediaries, publics, and the general marketing environment itself. Objective 3-2 delves into demographic factors, specifically detailing various generational cohorts such as Baby Boomers, Generation X, Millennials (Generation Y), and Generation Z, and also includes the economic environment. Objectives 3-3 and 3-4 shift focus to external environmental influences, with Objective 3-3 covering the natural and technological environments, and Objective 3-4 addressing the political and cultural environments. The structure is comparative, presenting distinct but related areas of environmental analysis for marketing strategy.
